**1.** Figure out your *"lifeline"*. It doesn't have to be huge or grandiose, just important to you. When I was depressed the only thing that kept me alive was knowing that there were 3 people that loved me even though I completely ignored them and was a total asshole to them for 6+ months -- they still loved me. I knew that no matter what, there will always be 3 things in my life that are still good and that was enough for me to hold on to in my darkest moments.
**2.** Set goals. I'm not talking "save the planet and make a fortune goals" I'm talking:
* Take a shower.
* Try to my best eat to breakfast.
* Take a 10 minute walk outside.
These are the things that will give your day to day life *purpose*. Write them down if you have to! The point of this is so that you don't lay around chain smoking cigarettes and weed and playing video games for 15+hours a day for 6 months straight. For the longest time I never set any goals and the only reason why I got up in the morning was to load another bowl -- not a healthy goal.
**3.** Volunteer. It doesn't matter if it is for 30 minutes or for a few hours. Bonus points if it is something that you care about. I'm really passionate about education and youth empowerment so I volunteered to read 1:1 with some Kindergarten-2nd grade kids at the local elementary schools. I hated myself and everything about my shitty and meaningless life, but seeing those kids faces light up when they saw me walk in to read with them *actually* made me smile. Giving your time away is the *best* thing that you could possibly ever do for yourself. If you can't find anything to volunteer for there is always need at your local Homeless Shelter. Those people can give 40+ hours of volunteer work if ask for it, and you are making a huge difference in other peoples lives too.
**4.** Do the small things. When you walk past a mirror try to smile at yourself. When you eat breakfast who gives a fuck if it is unhealthy waffles and nutella slathered in syrup is my goddamn favorite food. Have a favorite outfit that makes you feel awesome? Wear that son of a bitch, who cares if you aren't going out today! Time to suit up mother fuckers!
These are the four major things that helped me the most. **1.) Figure out your lifeline. 2.) Set small daily goals. The more the better. 3.) Volunteer. Giving your time away is the best thing that you can do for yourself and other people. 4.) Do the small things that used to make you happy.**
People say "one day at a time" but that was too much for me. Take it one step at a time. Try your best to stay sober. Shoot a text to someone that loves you and compliment them -- no need for a conversation, that's enough. Take care of yourself: shower, brush your teeth, clean your face, etc..
This post ended up being a lot longer than I intended, so I'm sorry for writing a novel. If you or anyone ever needs to talk feel free to PM me. It can feel cathartic to just have someone listen to you.
The last thing that I can't stress enough is that you aren't alone. What you are feeling lots of other people feel for no good reason. You aren't pathetic, you're awesome. One more time because it is so incredibly important:
**YOU ARE NOT ALONE.**

Checking your privilege is something that's important to do (and I am a white, middle class, male to be clear). I'm also gay, so I can talk about the ever present subtle homophobia in popular culture that you really only impacts someone if that are gay (I have no place to talk about race because I got the good end of the stick with my skin color).
Third.) Here are my experiences with subtle homophobia in popular culture:
**1.)** Remember in school when you had to fill out a family tree and there was a designated place for a Mom and a Dad? Very small things like this is ever-present in education and it taught me that the way that I feel isn't "normal". I learned about heterosexual couples in school from science to English to History to small projects like this in elementary school. There is no *explicit* "Being gay is bad" but rather by extreme omission it is very easy to internalize those feelings. I never learned about gay activists and the names like *Harvey Milk* or *Doris Fish* or *The Mattachine Society*. LGBTQ+ rights are completely ignored in school. :(
**2.)** The majority of Disney movies antagonist (bad guy) is nearly always some sort of gender-bender? Think about it. Aladdin, you get Jaffar (sp? w/e), Little Mermaid, you get the evil butch scary octopus lady (while all other women are very small, petite, and feminine). In Pocahontas, you get that weird short fat dude that always caries around a pug (which even the invading white men turn on.. so he is portrayed remarkably evil). I will admit that it has gotten *better* but instances like this still exist even in cartoons prevalent today. Breaking traditional gender performance is *evil*.
**3.** This part is the iffy-est due to consumer demographics. There are very few movies, books, and popular songs that really ever touch on Gay issues. Sure you have pop icons like Lady Gaga but she is a phenomenon. Most of the time if gay issues are mentioned it is made fun of, like:*"I Kissed a Girl*. Once again, this is the omission part. The firs time I ever heard a song (by an all gay punk band, no less) that was a dude singing about being attracted to other dudes it threw me into a little bit of an existential crisis because I've *never* heard same sex attraction sang about the same way normal love songs sing about heterosexual relationships.
I can keep going but my point is: **Prolonged silence and omission can be just as oppressive as someone yelling "Faggot!" down the street.** This is what "Checking your privilege" is about to me: Realizing that sometimes racism, sexism, homophobia is presented in nearly subconscious and subtle ways that it is hard to notice if it doesn't directly impact you (Hence why I have no right to talk about Race, Patriarchy, Classism, etc.. because I got the good end of the stick.. ) I'm just sometimes not aware of the implications of my actions even though I *never ever* intend it to be negative or oppressive -- it doesn't mean that it *can't* be negative or oppressive.
So.. uhh... Check your privilege you racists, homophobic, patriarchal bigots, you! #r/SRS!! (/sarcasm if no one got that...) (but seriously, it is important to critically examine your actions and sometimes just to sit down and listen to what someone has to say about something that doesn't always pertain to you. Don't be offended, it's not your fault. Just take it in stride as a potential learning opportunity.)
